comments.commentBody:
My life keeps happening.

Being one of 6 children(in the middle)and not 'most-favored', I learned early not to ask or expect anything.
Consequently when I left home I never reached back for financial help.

I bounced around teaching when I ran out of money; saying "hire the substitute" when given the choice.
Moving from the east coast to Tucson to La Jolla to Scottsdale, getting married and divorced, leaving the big home and most of the 'stuff' behind.

Then doing life all over again anywhichway:in a Green Stamp store, as a shopping investigator, working at Aris Gloves in NYC.
I pawned things, sold my possessions.
But I never declared bankruptcy and I always paid back all loans, from the likes of Beneficial Finance no less with its usury fees of the time.
Finally I grew into a love of stability to teach primary-grade children for 33 years.

One really great vignette:I did believe I had a back-up during my escapades.
Via my marquise diamond engagement ring which I pawned many times on the strength of its supposed value.
(Only later realizing that the stone had been switched years before during a late pawn❣️).

With time and the right genes I came to value Poetic Compression.
Small house, 'vintage' car, clothes dryingontheline, no cable, no maid, no gardener but lots of space and the most valuable of all-quiet.
Think Georgia O'Keefe-her sensibilities.

That's not to say I don't go for a long-stay in Paris or NYC. When I splurge I splurge..because I can afford to after all.

I retired at 41, so my advice is to not have children and to learn to delay gratification. I am not a millionaire, I didn't invent anything or get lucky with an investment. I was just prudent with finances and didn't have kids.

Here's some advice you won't get anywhere else. Make sure you find friends who are on the same page as you with respect to living life to fullest while living well below your means and investing for the future. If you have friends who dress in the latest fashions, dine out often, and drive the latest luxury SUVs, they will drag you down. We drifted away from friends like that while maintained our relationships with friends who appreciated the simpler things in life (BBQs and dinner parties at our homes, driving Hondas, traveling in economy, etc). We are not cheap at the least. We can easily send our kids to private universities (they chose public) and pay for all that other fluff but none of that would make us happier. As a result, at retirement, we are very comfortable (in fact, have more than we need to live fully)--same with our frugal friends. Our old friends who lived big? They all seem to be struggling financially (some long before they retired).
That whole "Search for Excellence" mentality is a cultural ball and chain that breaks up families and encourages depression.

The baby boomers have been the guinea pigs in our great national experiment in income equality. They worked hard all their lives and through three recessions and a mortgage crisis, half of them don't have a pot to urinate in, as my mother would have said.

In 10 years there will be a wave of elder poverty and need such as this country has never seen.

Pretty uninformative "article" - per the title, it would have been better to have had more in-depth responses from the elders. Much more valuable to have longer responses with good advice than the short comments as reported herein.

A new question should enter the lexicon; What do you want to do with second adulthood? Our society has not fully adapted to new reality, that we live a second adult life time compared to forebears from 1900.
With senior's better overall health far longer into life, we have opportunities for fulfillment, creatively, emotionally, spiritually and intellectually. Pushing 60 myself, I would tell the young journalists to consider what they would require to feel self actualized, and start working toward it in a balanced way.
And its worth adding, tell the kids that if we start creating age friendly city's now, they will be the real beneficiaries. Its not an old-versus young thing, for we all are united in aging...

We maxed out all deferred tax accounts (401k, IRA, 457), even in those years where we had to borrow money to do so. Consequently, we have our SS and payouts from retirement funds that will keep us at half our working incomes until well into our 90s, should we live that long. Our kids won't retire for 35 to 40 years, so the environment might be very different, but the gift of deferred tax income, I suspect, will still be of high value.

Yes,when you get a good job, with or without benefits, look into insurance, life if you have dependents and disability, for everyone. As a healthcare professional, I well knew that people have a 1 in 3 chance of being disabled (even somewhat long-term temporarily), even before age 65.

So I bought disability insurance and invested, starting in my late 20s, as much as I could into my company's offered benefits, etc. A close friend, also an MD, did the same. Consequently, when I became ill for a somewhat extended period and my friend came down with cancer, in our 30s, neither of us were wiped out during the time we received treatment and recovered.

As for my investments, part of it was luck and part of it was study but my investments had a rate of return of about 20% over the last decade. Some of my co-workers did not even read or investigate all the benefits our company offered until much later and missed out. Amazing what time and interest will do.

Absolutely agree! I have bought too many used cars that needed a $500 repair within the first six months of purchase. I realize this approach is not for everyone but finally, when I could afford it, I have bought new from a reputable company (my choice Toyota but I'm sure there are others out there) and have been very happy to trade off the higher initial price with lack of repair costs, downtime while car in shop, etc. My two cents.

Living abroad may seem appealing, but many come to realize that an  existence far from family and friends is a diminished life.  Online extended relationships cannot fully substitute for the real thing.  Think twice and twice again before uprooting yourself permanently.  Even a trial six months to a year abroad cannot compare to the reality of a long-term life away from all that was near and dear.  And if widowed abroad, make sure you have the resources to return, so as not to be entirely alone in your remaining years.  Don't burn your bridges.

Born in 1950 I find it very difficult to give my children (born in the early 1980s) life/career/financial advice owing to the vast differences in the country, the economy, & the world that have occurred. I also find that my expectations of what they might want in their lives and what I wanted in mine are vastly different and it's unfair & unhelpful for me to project myself onto them. I feel I can only be helpful to them by example and I'm not at all sure that I'm a helpful exemplar. Each generation must, in the end, find it's own way forward.

I can't believe how early in life so many of these people no longer had to work.

In my own circle of family, friends, and HS classmates (1964), it seems that the only group that got to retire early and well have been government employees. Teachers, law enforcement, like that.

I think for most of us, the age of retirement, and the quality of retirement has more to do with life decisions and the consequences. Some you think will go one way, but they go another. Some you think will be solid, but they are quicksand. Some will go as you thought. When that happens, don't think you are really smart. Other people made the same decision, and it didn't work out. How many people were all set with investments until The Second Republican Great Depression?

In my (kinda) old age, if there is one thing I've learned, it's the truth in the old adage, "Man plans, God laughs."

I spent 40 years teaching and coaching in public education.  Since I coached all 3 seasons during the school year I was very busy.  For the past 8 years I have been an assistant coach in private schools.  Not being a head coach takes off pressure and the amount of duties.  I enjoy still being involved with kids.  My hobbies take up the rest of my time.  It's important to be active.  Forming good health habits make ageing much easier.

In many ways, this article and its comments are more a reflection of older people (myself included) preaching to the choir... ourselves. Older people dispensing advice has been around for millennia; in the end it's more self-reflection than antidote. Young people are blessed with a blank slate to create their own story.

The journey of our life is about gaining wisdom and experience through trial and error, love and loss, happiness and sadness, ease and dis-ease. While well-meaning, no one can save us from ourselves, nor would we want it. If one avenue of experience is cut off, life will throw us another. There is no escaping the inevitable challenges; "mistakes" will always be made and overcome through accompanying wisdom. It is the nature of the journey.

It's what each of us is here for... and will experience in our own unique way. No matter one's age, we must always look forward to the distant horizon, not the rear view window; as the saying goes...We're not going that way.

C from Atlanta asks, "Is the problem really the Trump Administration? Would we being going through this if former Secretary Hillary Clinton hadn't turned the department into her own personal fief? "

Yes, it really is The Con Don and his Top 1% Global Financial Elite Robber Baron/ Radical Religion Good Old Boys' Party/ Cabal, C. Do you happen to remember all the lies heaped on Ms. Hillary Rodham Clinton for her speeches to Goldman Sachs? Did you happen to notice The Con Don has loaded his "cabinet" with those Robber Barons who, as he said, are "crooked" and plan to destroy democracy in America.

Every single thing The Con Don said about Ms. Rodham-Clinton is a reflection of himself - not her. She is still the most qualified candidate to ever run to be President of the United States of America and a WOMAN of honor, courage and love of democracy.

America allowed The Robber Baron Party to give us a fascist instead. STUPID AND DEPLORABLE.

Mr. Walker needs to understand something: it is no longer 2010.

In 2017, the threats Republicans face come from within their own party, and not from liberals. Your party rejected three classic conservatives (Bush, Kasich and Rubio) and rightist conservative (Cruz) in favor of a demagogue whose only real interests are power and adulation. Trump is a loose cannon who will take your party in one of two directions: he'll either transform it into a far right, populist part that revels in racism and xenophobia, or he'll lead you into the worst political scandal since Watergate.

Liberal protesters are small potatoes. Republicans need to stand strong against a movement that is undermining their party from within. At some point, each of you - Republican Governors, Senators, and Congressmen - need to decide what is more important to you- party loyalty, or to the rule of law, the independence our system of government from foreign interference, and the rights and freedoms spelled out in our Constitution.

LChina's only ally is NK: China will have to do something about NK's whackadoodle leader. NK and is becoming an albatross around China's political neck.

Frankly, China has more political poker chips to make NK conform, than the USA does.

I wonder about the corrosive effect of Nixon's Chennault spoiler gambit. The political calculation to "throw a monkey wrench" in Johnson's 68 peace initiative with the beligerent factions.

Could a peace deal or detente have been reached is a great unknown.

I remember the '67 elections. I remember the Johnson administration had been making a big deal for years that the war was all about getting S. Vietnam to have elections and now they had and wasn't that just great. We were there to protect democracy. Being young and naive, I bought that. I also remember the next spring ('68) reading a little tiny blurb in the newspaper just casually mentioning that Thieu had arrested and jailed the guy who came in 2nd in the election (running on a peace platform of negotiating w the VC) on what even then struck me as a trumped up charge.
The opponent was Truong Dinh Dzu (here's a notice of his sentencing in Sept http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1967/09/16/page/21/article/viet-runne... but he was arrested in May)
To me at the time, that was as if Johnson had had Goldwater arrested after the '64 election. It opened my eyes for the first time to the snake oil we were being sold (and have been ever since) that American intervention was all about protecting democracy. Thieu was no more a democrat (little d) than Ho Chi Minh---probably less so. Yet 10s of thousands of Americans and millions of SE Asians died to put him, and men like him, in power. Baloney.

I like the Trib news clip a lot. Check out the headlines: Vietnam! Vietnam! Vietnam! And that was '67, before many more American troops poured in (and many more lies were told). The hypocrisy of those years left its stamp on many of us for years to come.

I went to Vietnam in 1971 as a 1LT in Military Police Battalion. The American combat troops had largely been withdrawn. The Vietnamese army had primary responsibility for combat operations against the NVA and VC. Our bases were periodically attacked and rocketed. The roads were mined and dangerous.
In 1972 there was a massive invasion by North Vietnam. The Vietnamese fought valiantly. With American air power the invasion was stopped. American antiwar efforts saw American airpower withdrawn while the NVA was supplied by China and Russia.
I have been reading Vietnam by Christopher Gorsha. It is an incredibly eye opening book. I was so ignorant. The complex internal divisions in Vietnam between the North, Central and Southern Regions basically meant there were three countries, two of which were anticommunist.
It is difficult to imagine a military victory by America given the social and political complexity. South Vietnam did not have the geography of Korea with the 38th Parallel. An invasion of North Vietnam? So the South collapses in 1975. The Russians won that war in the Cold War and then became enmeshed in Afghanistan. The American liberals saw the South consigned to communism and hell.
So what did I understand at the time? Not much. The definition of "winning" had changed as evidenced by the quagmires in Iraq, Afghanistan and now Syria. What did our generals learn? Not much.
Western Democracies did prevail in the Cold War.

This is a good series.
I was there, as a protester stateside and in Vietnam as an officer of Marines.
The younger folks who care about Vietnam at all are too often idiot Republicans who claim it was a war to protect democracy there, and we should have fought harder. Not that any of them would ever consider serving in the military. I hope some of them read this for a little reality therapy but my hopes are not high.

Wonderfully insightful article, very well researched and written. However, if one chooses to use big words in Dickensian fashion, it's best to use them correctly. "Arriviste" is a noun, thus it shouldn't be used to modify the adjective "arrogant" -- that should be the job of an adverb. That sentence, in the 8th paragraph, should have gone something like, "An arrogant arriviste . . ." Either way, it's almost redundant, but the alliteration is lovely, granted. Just sayin' . . .
Communists ARE undemocratic. Stalin is an excellent example of that, and a very evil man in other ways. I diverge from Steve in that I would not support a Hitler against a Stalin.

Steve,

I think you missed the point of the article. Of course there weren’t elections in North Vietnam, just as there weren’t elections in Communist China or Communist Russia. The whole purpose of our being in South Vietnam was to build a democracy as opposed to the communist regime in the north. This article tries to describe one of the reasons for that US failure at nation building.

Since the US is still trying to build democratic nations a study of past failures can help us be more successful in the future.
